verses.text: The sons of Judah: Perez, Hezron, Carmi, Hur, and Shobal.
verses.comment: This verse lists the descendants of Judah, one of the central tribes in the biblical story, emphasizing God's purpose working through family lines.

verses.text: Reaiah the son of Shobal fathered Jahath, and Jahath fathered Ahumai and Lahad. These are the families of the Zorathites.
verses.comment: Genealogies like these provide essential roots for understanding God's ongoing faithfulness and the historical grounding of salvation history.

verses.text: These were the sons of Etam: Jezreel, Ishma, and Idbash; and the name of their sister was Hazzelelponi.
verses.comment: The inclusion of Hazzelelponi, a woman, highlights the integral but often subtle roles women played in salvation history.

verses.text: Penuel fathered Gedor, and Ezer fathered Hushah. These were the sons of Hur, the firstborn of Ephrathah, the father of Bethlehem.
verses.comment: Bethlehem, later the birthplace of Jesus, is identified here, foreshadowing the fulfillment of messianic prophecy (Micah 5:2).

verses.text: Ashhur, the father of Tekoa, had two wives, Helah and Naarah:
verses.comment: Polygamy was recorded historically, yet the unfolding revelation of Scripture would later show God's plan for marriage as unity between one man and one woman.

verses.text: Naarah bore him Ahuzzam, Hepher, Temeni, and Haahashtari. These were the sons of Naarah.
verses.comment: Records of multiple children in tribes reinforce God's blessing of fruitfulness and multiply the chosen people.

verses.text: The sons of Helah: Zereth, Izhar, and Ethnan.
verses.comment: Genealogies such as these preserve vital links between the generations, an important theme echoed throughout Scripture.

verses.text: Koz fathered Anub, Zobebah, and the families of Aharhel the son of Harum.
verses.comment: While some names are obscure, their recorded inclusion shows the value given to every member within the family of faith.

verses.text: Jabez was more honorable than his brothers. His mother named him Jabez, saying, 'Because I bore him in pain.'
verses.comment: Jabez stands out not only for his birth, but for his character and relationship with God, which the next verse highlights. His story shows the importance of personal holiness.

verses.text: And Jabez called on the God of Israel, saying: 'Oh, that You would bless me and enlarge my territory, and that Your hand would be with me, and that You would keep me from harm so that I might not cause pain!' And God granted his request.
verses.comment: Jabez’s prayer is famous for its boldness and faith, showing the effectiveness of prayer and the heart of trust before God—a lesson for all believers.

verses.text: Chelub, the brother of Shuhah, fathered Mehir, who was the father of Eshton.
verses.comment: Chelub (Caleb) links to the line of faithful leaders, connecting God's promises to leaders raised up among His people.

verses.text: Eshton fathered Beth-rapha, Paseah, and Tehinnah, the father of Ir-nahash. These are the men of Recah.
verses.comment: These details show the extension of families into various towns and settlements, helping establish the ongoing inheritance and order in Israel.

verses.text: The sons of Kenaz: Othniel and Seraiah. The son of Othniel: Hathath.
verses.comment: Othniel becomes Israel's first judge, prefiguring the idea of God-ordained leaders who judge and deliver Israel, pointing to the ultimate leadership of Christ.

verses.text: Meonothai fathered Ophrah. Seraiah fathered Joab, the father of Ge-harashim (so-called because they were craftsmen).
verses.comment: The mention of craftsmen indicates the importance of skilled work and the practical gifts used in building up Israel, just as all Christian gifts serve a larger purpose in the body of believers (1 Cor. 12:4-7).

verses.text: The sons of Caleb the son of Jephunneh: Iru, Elah, and Naam. The son of Elah: Kenaz.
verses.comment: This continues the lineage of faithful Caleb, whose courage and faith are celebrated in Israel’s journey to the promised land.

verses.text: The sons of Jehallelel: Ziph, Ziphah, Tiria, and Asarel.
verses.comment: Many genealogies are simply listed, but they document the entire people of God; every individual contributes to His larger plan.

verses.text: The sons of Ezrah: Jether, Mered, Epher, and Jalon. Mered married Bithiah, the daughter of Pharaoh, and she bore him Miriam, Shammai, and Ishbah the father of Eshtemoa.
verses.comment: A Hebrew man marrying an Egyptian princess is unusual and shows God's providence reaching beyond ethnic lines, reminiscent of Moses’ own family circumstance (Ex. 2:21).

verses.text: And his (Jewish) wife bore Jered the father of Gedor, Heber the father of Soco, and Jekuthiel the father of Zanoah.
verses.comment: Noting his (Jewish) wife, in contrast with his Egyptian wife, highlights the importance of covenant identity.

verses.text: The sons of the wife of Hodiah, the sister of Naham: the father of Keilah the Garmite, and Eshtemoa the Maacathite.
verses.comment: Further records confirm the thorough care God’s people took to maintain knowledge of their lineage and land ownership—as promised in the covenant (Gen. 17:8).

verses.text: The sons of Shimon: Amnon, Rinnah, Ben-hanan, and Tilon. The sons of Ishi: Zoheth and Ben-zoheth.
verses.comment: These names demonstrate the expansion and population of Israel, in line with God's original command to be fruitful and multiply (Gen. 1:28).

verses.text: The sons of Shelah the son of Judah: Er, the father of Lecah, Laadah the father of Mareshah, the families of the house of workers of fine linen at Beth-ashbea;
verses.comment: The emphasis on workers of fine linen recalls how Israel was given priestly roles and foreshadows the spiritual priesthood of all believers (1 Pet. 2:9).

verses.text: And Jokim, men of Cozeba, and Joash and Saraph who ruled in Moab and Jashubi-lehem. (But these are ancient records.)
verses.comment: ‘Ruled in Moab’ records how Israelites came to influence other lands, showing God's promise extends beyond their immediate borders.

verses.text: These were the potters and inhabitants of Netaim and Gederah; they lived there with the king for his work.
verses.comment: The service to the king highlights both practical trades and religious life as sacred callings, reminiscent of service in God’s true kingdom.

verses.text: The sons of Simeon: Nemuel, Jamin, Jarib, Zerah, and Shaul.
verses.comment: The tribe of Simeon is carefully preserved, even though they are less prominent later, reminding us of the value of all tribes before God.

verses.text: Shallum was his son, Mibsam his son, and Mishma his son.
verses.comment: The repetition of 'his son' maintains clarity of lineage and succession, important in showing God’s faithfulness through each generation.

verses.text: The sons of Mishma: Hammuel his son, Zaccur his son, Shimei his son.
verses.comment: Names like these affirm individual place and worth—echoing Paul’s later teaching that all are one in Christ Jesus (Gal. 3:28).

verses.text: Shimei had sixteen sons and six daughters, but his brothers did not have many children, nor did all their family multiply as the people of Judah.
verses.comment: The distinction in blessing and growth echoes God’s sovereign choice and purpose—some tribes grew larger, others smaller, by God’s hidden wisdom.

verses.text: They lived at Beersheba, Moladah, Hazar-shual,
verses.comment: Lists of towns show the physical roots of each tribe, foreshadowing the later call to unity within the greater promised land of God’s people.

verses.text: Bilhah, Ezem, Tolad,
verses.comment: More towns are listed to record the fullness and reach of the tribe’s settlement.

verses.text: Bethuel, Hormah, Ziklag,
verses.comment: Ziklag is famous as David’s refuge—a reminder that these lands played roles in the lineage of the Messiah.

verses.text: Beth-marcaboth, Hazar-susim, Beth-biri, and Shaaraim—these were their cities until David reigned.
verses.comment: David’s reign is a key moment when Israel’s unity is realized, prefiguring Christ’s reign as the true and ultimate King.

verses.text: And their villages were Etam, Ain, Rimmon, Tochen, and Ashan—five cities—
verses.comment: The record of villages preserves full knowledge of their territory and participation in the nation’s covenant.

verses.text: along with all their surrounding villages as far as Baal. These were their settlements, and they kept their genealogical records.
verses.comment: Continuous records ensured the integrity and unity of God’s people, just as the church maintains continuity with the ancient faith.

verses.text: Meshobab, Jamlech, Joshah the son of Amaziah,
verses.comment: As individual names are recalled, we’re reminded that God knows each member of His family.

verses.text: Joel, Jehu the son of Joshibiah, son of Seraiah, son of Asiel,
verses.comment: The careful mention of multiple generations highlights unbroken succession—something later leaders and apostles would model.

verses.text: Elioenai, Jaakobah, Jeshohaiah, Asaiah, Adiel, Jesimiel, Benaiah,
verses.comment: Long lists testify to Israel’s faithfulness in recording their history and the names of those who serve in various ways.

verses.text: Ziza the son of Shiphi, son of Allon, son of Jedaiah, son of Shimri, son of Shemaiah—
verses.comment: Notable men may be remembered for a line of faithful service across generations.

verses.text: these, mentioned by name, were leaders in their clans. Their families increased greatly.
verses.comment: Leadership is recognized and remembered, foreshadowing the later role of elders, bishops, and deacons in the orderly government of God’s people (1 Tim 3:1-13).

verses.text: And they went to the entrance of Gedor, to the east side of the valley, to seek pasture for their flocks.
verses.comment: Seeking pasture shows Israel as a shepherding people, a theme of God as Shepherd pointing ultimately to Christ the Good Shepherd (John 10:11).

verses.text: They found rich, good pasture, and the land was spacious, quiet, and peaceful; for former inhabitants lived there who were of Ham.
verses.comment: The land was already occupied, but God’s people were called to possess it just as Christians are called to lay hold of God’s promises.

verses.text: These, whose names are mentioned, came in the days of Hezekiah king of Judah and attacked their tents and the Meunites who were found there, and devoted them to destruction as it is to this day. They settled in their place because there was pasture for their flocks.
verses.comment: Obedience to God's commands sometimes meant difficult actions, mirrored in the call to spiritual battle and claiming our spiritual inheritance through faith.

verses.text: And some of them, five hundred men of the sons of Simeon, went to Mount Seir, with Pelatiah, Neariah, Rephaiah, and Uzziel, the sons of Ishi, leading them.
verses.comment: The mention of specific leaders reminds believers that legitimate authority and apostolic succession play key roles in preserving the faith and unity of God’s people.

verses.text: And they destroyed the remnant of the Amalekites who had escaped, and they have lived there to this day.
verses.comment: The final defeat of the Amalekites fulfills God’s earlier commands—showing that God’s plans and judgments always come to pass. This also points forward to Christ’s total victory over sin and death (1 Cor. 15:54-57).
